document.masterDocTitle: Nomenclatural Studies Toward a World List of Diptera Genus-Group Names Part VII: Johann Wilhelm Meigen

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Nomenclatural Studies Toward a World List of Diptera Genus-Group Names Part VII: Johann Wilhelm Meigen

heading.emphasis: Catalog of Diptera Genus-Group Names of Johann Wilhelm Meigen

subSubSection.paragraph:
1 .
Acrocera Meigen , 1803 : 266
. ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Syrphus globulus Panzer, 1802
. TYPE SPECIES:
Syrphus globulus Panzer, 1802
[=
Syrphus orbiculus Fabricius, 1787
], by monotypy. CURRENT STATUS: Valid genus [
teste Winterton & Barraclough (2017: 989)
]. FAMILY: ACROCERIDAE . REMARKS: Panzer’s type species is sometimes dated as 1804 [e.g., Schlinger (1980: 378); Nartshuk (1988: 192)]. Evenhuis (1997: 600) gave the date of publication for Heft 86 in Panzer’s “ Faunae insectorum Germanicae ” as 17 May 1803 , but recent research (Alonso-Zarazaga & Evenhuis 2017) has shown this Heft (Panzer 1802) to have been published on or before 9 May 1802 .

2 .
Actina Meigen , 1804 : 116
.

TYPE SPECIES :
Actina chalybea Meigen, 1804
, by subsequent designation (Coquillett 1910a: 503)
.
FAMILY: STRATIOMYIDAE .

REMARKS: Earlier designations of
Beris tibialis Meigen, 1820
(Westwood 1840: 130) and of
Beris nitens Latreille, 1805
(Rondani 1863: 87; Dallas 1866: 646; Brauer 1882: 30) are invalid because they are of nominal species that were not originally included.

3 .
Actora Meigen , 1826
: xii , 403 , pl . 54 .

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Actora aestuum Meigen, 1826
.

TYPE
SPECIES :
Actora aestuum Meigen, 1826
[=
Helcomyza ustula Curtis, 1825b
], by monotypy.

CURRENT STATUS: Junior synonym of
Helcomyza Curtis, 1825b
[
teste Mathis (2011: 273)
].
FAMILY: HELCOMYZIDAE .
[Adromyza] Meigen , 1830b : viii .

CURRENT STATUS: Incorrect subsequent spelling of
Agromyza Fallén, 1810
.
FAMILY: AGROMYZIDAE .
REMARKS: Criteria for making this name available as an emendation were not found to be fulfilled in this work.

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Aedes cinereus Wiedemann
in Meigen, 1818a (as “
Aed. cinereus
. Hoffmgg.”).

TYPE
SPECIES :
Aedes cinereus Wiedemann
in Meigen, 1818a (as “
Aed. cinereus
. Hoffmgg.”), by monotypy.
FAMILY: CULICIDAE .

REMARKS: Authorship of the type species is “Wiedemann in Meigen” since the characters given to differentiate the species are by Wiedemann alone (quoted material). Meigen only provided the name (a Hoffmannsegg cabinet name) attributing it to Hoffmansegg.

5 .
Agatachys Meigen , 1830a : 343
[ 1830b : 343 ].

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Tachydromia celeripes Meigen, 1830a
(with
Agatachys flavipes Meigen, 1830a
in synonymy).

TYPE
SPECIES :
Tachydromia celeripes Meigen, 1830a
(with
Agatachys flavipes Meigen, 1830a
in synonymy), by monotypy.

CURRENT STATUS: Suppressed for the purposes of the Principle of Priority but not for those of the Principle of Homonymy by action of I.C.Z.N. (1997b: 200 [Opinion 1881]); senior (but invalid) synonym of
Stilpon Loew, 1859
[
teste
I.C.Z.N. (1997b: 200)].
FAMILY: HYBOTIDAE .

REMARKS: Originally proposed in synonymy with
Tachydromia Meigen, 1803
, but made available by subsequent usage as a valid senior synonym of
Stilpon Loew, 1859
by Coquillett (1910a: 504). Application was made to the ICZN by Cumming & Evenhuis (1996) to conserve
Stilpon Loew, 1859
by suppressing
Agatachys Meigen, 1830a
. The I.C.Z.N. (1997b: 200 [Opinion 1881]) voted in favor of the application to suppress
Agatachys Meigen, 1830a
for the purposes of the Principle of Priority but not for those of the Principle of Homonymy, thus preserving the genus
Stilpon Loew, 1859
.
[ Amasia ] Meigen , 1800 : 20 .

CURRENT STATUS: Unavailable name; work suppressed for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]); treated under
Penthetria Meigen, 1803
[
teste Hendel (1908: 50)
].
FAMILY: BIBIONIDAE .
REMARKS: Subsequently made available by Meigen in Hendel (1908) (see next entry).

6 .
Amasia Meigen
in Hendel
, 1908 : 50 .
ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES: None.

FIRST INCLUDED SPECIES :
Penthetria funebris Meigen, 1804
[as “
Amasia funebris (Meig.)
”] (in Bezzi 1911: 39).

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Penthetria funebris Meigen, 1804
[as “
Amasia funebris (Meig.)
”], by subsequent monotypy (Bezzi 1911: 39).

CURRENT STATUS : Preoccupied by
Amasia Dejean, 1835
;
Amasia Chapuis, 1874
; junior synonym of
Penthetria Meigen, 1803
[
teste Evenhuis & Pape (2017: 22)
].
FAMILY: BIBIONIDAE .

REMARKS:
Amasia
was originally proposed by Meigen (1800: 20) without included species and later made unavailable by the suppression of the work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hendel (1908: 50) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) and to treat
Amasia
as valid, which makes the name available from that work with Meigen as author. However, Hendel (1908) did not include any species and, subsequently,
Amasia
had been treated as a “
Genus dubium
” (e.g., Stone 1941). The first included species we could find in this study is
Penthetria funebris Meigen, 1804
[as “
Amasia funebris (Meig.)
”] (in Bezzi 1911: 39), in which the type species is by subsequent monotypy. Sabrosky (1999: 43), unaware of Bezzi’s (1911) inclusion of a species, indicated that Rohdendorf (1951: plate 65, figure 28B) had included a species (
Crapitula motschulskii Gimmerthal, 1845
) in
Amasia
, but this was later.
Penthetria funebris Meigen, 1804
is currently treated in
Penthetria Meigen, 1803
[
teste Krivosheina (1986: 314)
], which makes
Amasia Hendel, 1908 a
junior synonym of
Penthetria Meigen, 1803
. NB: Bezzi (1911: 39) indicated an earlier mention of
Amasia funebris
by (Schmitz 1909: 79), but a check of that article showed it to list the species as “
Penthetria holosericea
” without mentioning
Amasia
or
funebris
anywhere in the article.
[ Amphinome ] Meigen , 1800 : 15 .

CURRENT STATUS: Unavailable name; work suppressed for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]); treated under
Limonia Meigen, 1803
[
teste Sabrosky (1999: 44)
].
FAMILY: LIMONIIDAE .
REMARKS : Subsequently proposed in synonymy by Hendel (1908) and made available by Coquillett (1910: 505) (see next entry).

7 .
Amphinome Meigen
in Hendel
, 1908 : 47 .

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Tipula tripunctata Fabricius, 1781
,
Tipula sexpunctata Fabricius, 1781
[as “
6- punctata
”];
Tipula quadrimaculata Linnaeus, 1761
[as “
4- maculata
... Fabr.”];
Tipula replicata Linnaeus, 1758
[as “
replicata
... Fabr.”];
Tipula rivosa Linnaeus, 1758
[as “
rivosa
... Fabr.”).

TYPE
SPECIES :
Tipula tripunctata Fabricius, 1781
[preoccupied by
Tipula tripunctata Mu
̈ller, 1764; =
Tipula phragmitidis Schrank, 1781
], by subsequent designation (Coquillett 1910a: 505).

CURRENT STATUS: Preoccupied by
Amphinome Bruguière, 1792
; junior synonym of
Limonia Meigen, 1803
[
teste Evenhuis & Pape (2017: 23)
].
FAMILY: LIMONIIDAE .

REMARKS:
Amphinome
was originally proposed by Meigen without included species and later made unavailable by the suppression of the work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hendel (1908: 47) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) but treated the name in synonymy with
Limonia Meigen, 1803
. Coquillett (1910a: 505) was the first to treat the name as valid and thus make the name available. Because Coquillett was dealing with the names as given in Hendel (1908), the authorship is attributed as Meigen in Hendel (1908) following ICZN Code Art. 67.7. Hendel (1908) included five available species-group names, but did not select a type species from among them. Coquillett (1910a: 505) was the first to designate
Tipula tripunctata Fabricius, 1781
, as type species of
Amphinome
from these five originally included species.
Tipula tripunctata Fabricius, 1781
is currently treated in
Limonia Meigen, 1803
[
teste Sabrosky 1999: 4
)], which makes
Amphinome Meigen
in Hendel, 1908 a junior synonym of
Limonia Meigen, 1803
.

8 .
Ananta Meigen , 1838 : 283
; pl . 73 .
ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES: Not applicable.

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Elomya claripennis Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
[=
Phasia lateralis Meigen, 1824
], automatic [by designation of the same species (by subsequent designation by Townsend 1916: 6) for
Elomya Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
].

CURRENT STATUS: Unnecessary new replacement name for
Elomya Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
; junior synonym of
Elomya Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
[
teste Dupuis (1963: 80)
].
FAMILY: TACHINIDAE .

REMARKS: Some workers have treated this name as a proposal of a new genus-group name [e.g., Brauer 1893: 496, who proposed
Phasia lateralis Meigen, 1824
(one of the species included in Meigen (1838)) as a type species for it]. However we treat it as a new replacement name for
Elomya Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
, which requires a designation from one of the originally included species in Robineau-Desvoidy (1830) (
Phasia lateralis Meigen, 1824
was not one of the originally included species). Meigen (1838: 283) split his prior concept of
Phasia (Meigen 1824: 202)
into two genera:
Phasia
and “
Elomyia
” of Macquart. Meigen (1838: 283) considered that
Elomya Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
(as “
Elomyia Macqu.
”) which, because it should be spelled as “ Helomyia ”, was too similar to
Helomyza Fallén, 1820
to be maintained and proposed
Ananta
to replace it. This nominal genus is missing in Herting & Dely-Draskovits (1993). We follow Dupuis (1963) who treated
Ananta Meigen, 1838
as a junior synonym of
Elomya Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
.

9 .
Anapera Meigen , 1830a : 234
, pl . 64 [ 1830b : ix , 234 , pl . 64 ].

TYPE
SPECIES :
Oxypterum kirbyanum Leach, 1817
, automatic [by designation of the same species (by subsequent designation by Westwood 1840: 154) for
Oxypterum Leach, 1817
].

CURRENT STATUS: Unnecessary new replacement name for
Oxypterum Leach, 1817
; junior synonym of
Crataerina Olfers, 1816
[
teste Soós & Hůrka (1986: 218)
].
FAMILY: HIPPOBOSCIDAE .

REMARKS: Blanchard in Audouin et al . (1846: 182) designated
Ornithobia pallida Meigen, 1830a
(as “
Anapera pallida
”) as the type species, but this is invalid as it was not an originally included species in
Oxypterum Leach, 1817
. Meigen (1830a: 235) considered the spelling of
Oxypterum Leach, 1817
to be too similar to Oxyptera Gistel, 1848 and proposed
Anapera
to replace it: “ Bei Dr. Leach heist diese Gattung Oxypterum ; allein dieser Name kommt zu sehr mit Ocyptera überrein, als dass er konnte beibehalten werden. Ich habe ihn deswegen gegen Anapera (verstümmmelt) vertauscht. ” [Dr. Leach calls this genus
Oxypterum
; but this name comes too close to
Ocyptera
for it to be preserved. That is why I swapped it for
Anapera
(mutilated).] However,
Oxypterum Leach, 1817
is not preoccupied by Oxyptera Gistel, 1848, thus the name is an unnecessary replacement name.

10 .
Anisomera Meigen , 1818a
: xxxv , 210 , pl . 7 [ 1818b : xxxv , 210 , pl . 7 ].

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Anisomera obscura Meigen & Wiedemann
in Meigen, 1818a (as “
Anis. obscura
. Hgg.”)

TYPE
SPECIES :
Anisomera obscura Meigen & Wiedemann
in Meigen, 1818a (as “
Anis. obscura
. Hgg.”). by monotypy.

CURRENT STATUS : Junior synonym of
Hexatoma Latreille, 1809
[
teste Ribeiro & Santos (2016: 83)
].
FAMILY: LIMONIIDAE .

REMARKS: Authorship of the type species is “Meigen & Wiedemann in Meigen” since the characters to differentiate the species were by both original material by Meigen and quoted material from Wiedemann.

11 .
Anisopus Meigen , 1803 : 264
.
ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES: None.

FIRST INCLUDED SPECIES:
Anisopus fuscus Meigen, 1804
;
Anisopus nebulosus Meigen, 1804
(in Meigen, 1804: 103).

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Anisopus fuscus Meigen, 1804
[=
Tipula fuscata Fabricius, 1775
], by subsequent designation (Coquillett 1910a: 507).

CURRENT STATUS : Junior synonym of
Sylvicola Harris, 1779
[
teste Amorim et al . (2016: 17)
].
FAMILY: ANISOPODIDAE .

12 .
Anopheles Meigen , 1818a : 10
.

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES :
Culex bifurcatus Linnaeus, 1758
(with
Culex trifurcatus Fabricius, 1794
and
Culex claviger Meigen, 1804
in synonymy);
Anopheles maculipennis Meigen, 1818a
(as “
An. maculipennis
. Hoffmgg.”).

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Anopheles maculipennis Meigen, 1818a
, by subsequent designation (I.C.Z.N. 1959: 155 [Opinion 547])
.
FAMILY: CULICIDAE .

13 .
Anthomyia Meigen , 1803 : 281
.

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Musca meditabunda Fabricius, 1781
;
Musca pluvialis Linnaeus, 1758
(as “
pluvialis
... Fabr.).

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Musca pluvialis Linnaeus, 1758
, by subsequent designation (Latreille 1810: 444)
.
FAMILY: ANTHOMYIIDAE .

EMENDATIONS:
Anthomya Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
(unjustified);
Anthomyza Zetterstedt, 1837: 42
(unjustified).

14 .
Anthracia Meigen , 1838 : 268
.

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Dexia caminaria Meigen, 1826
.

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Dexia caminaria Meigen, 1826
[=
Musca halterata Panzer, 1797b
], by monotypy.

CURRENT STATUS: Preoccupied by
Anthracia Hübner, 1823
; junior synonym of
Nyctia Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
[
teste Pape (1996: 165)
].
FAMILY: SARCOPHAGIDAE .

[ Antiopa ] Meigen , 1800 : 32 . CURRENT STATUS: Unavailable name; work suppressed for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]); treated under
Chrysotoxum Meigen, 1803
[
teste Peck (1988: 56)
].
FAMILY: SYRPHIDAE .
REMARKS: Subsequently proposed in synonymy by Hendel (1908) and made available by Coquillett (1910) (see next entry).

15 .
Antiopa Meigen
in Hendel
, 1908 : 61 .
ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES: None.

FIRST INCLUDED SPECIES:
Musca bicincta Linnaeus, 1758
(in Coquillett 1910a: 508).

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Musca bicincta Linnaeus, 1758
by subsequent designation (Coquillett 1910a: 508)
.

CURRENT STATUS : Preoccupied by
Antiopa Alder & Hancock, 1848
;
Antiopa Stål, 1863
; junior synonym of
Chrysotoxum Meigen, 1803
[
teste Evenhuis & Pape (2017: 24)
].
FAMILY: SYRPHIDAE .

REMARKS:
Antiopa
was originally proposed by Meigen without included species and later made unavailable by the suppression of the work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hoyle (1902: 214) treated the name as a senior homonym of
Antiopa Alder & Hancock, 1848
, but did not treat it as valid, thus it was still unavailable in that work. Hendel (1908: 61) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) but treated the name in synonymy with
Chrysotoxum Meigen, 1803
; however no species were included in the genus in this work. Coquillett (1910a: 508) was the first to treat the name as valid and thus make the name available there. Because Coquillett was dealing with the names as given in Hendel (1908), the authorship is attributed as Meigen in Hendel (1908) following ICZN Code Art. 67.7. The first included species we could find was
Musca bicincta Linnaeus, 1758
in Coquillett (1910a: 508), which is thus the type species by subsequent designation.
Musca bicincta Linnaeus, 1758
is currently treated in
Chrysotoxum Meigen, 1803
[
teste Sabrosky (1999: 44)
], which makes
Antiopa Meigen
in Hendel, 1908 a junior synonym of
Chrysotoxum Meigen, 1803
.
[Antomyia] Meigen , 1826 : pl . 44 .

CURRENT STATUS: Incorrect subsequent spelling of
Anthomyia Meigen, 1803
.
FAMILY: ANTHOMYIIDAE .
REMARKS: Criteria for making this name available as an emendation were not found to be fulfilled in this work.
[Apivora] Meigen , 1800 : 37 .

CURRENT STATUS: Unavailable name; work suppressed for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]); treated under
Volucella Geoffroy, 1762
[
teste Sabrosky (1999: 51)
].
FAMILY: SYRPHIDAE .

REMARKS: Evenhuis & Pape (2017: 24) mistakenly claimed this name to be treated as valid by Hendel (1908), which would have made the name available there with the authorship as Meigen in Hendel, 1908. The fact that Hendel (1908) only treated as valid those names in boldface and Apivora was not in boldface was missed. Instead, Hendel (1908) treated Apivora in synonymy with
Volucella Geoffroy, 1762
. A search of the literature during this study did not find any subsequent usage of this name as valid before 1961 and thus it remains unavailable.

16 .
Ascia Meigen , 1822
: ix , 185 , pl . 27 .

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Syrphus podagricus Fabricius, 1781
(with
Musca elongata Schrank, 1803
and
Musca ichneumonea Linnaeus, 1758
in synonymy);
Ascia lanceolata Meigen, 1822
;
Ascia floralis Meigen, 1822
;
Ascia dispar Meigen, 1822
;
Ascia hastata Meigen & Wiedemann
in Meigen, 1822;
Ascia quadripunctata Meigen, 1822
;
Ascia interrupta Meigen, 1822
(as “
Asc. interrupta
. Meg.”);
Ascia nitidula Meigen, 1822
(as “
Asc. nitidula
. Meg.”);
Ascia aenea Meigen, 1822
(as “
Asc. aenea Meg.
”);
Ascia geniculata Meigen, 1822
.

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Syrphus podagricus Fabricius, 1781
, by subsequent designation (Froriep 1825a: 368)
.

CURRENT STATUS: Preoccupied by
Ascia Scopoli, 1777
; senior (but invalid) synonym of
Neoascia Williston, 1887
[
teste Peck (1988: 143)
].
FAMILY: SYRPHIDAE .

REMARKS : Previous catalogs [e.g., Peck (1988: 143), Sabrosky (1999: 55)] listed Westwood’s (1840: 136) designation of
Syrphus podagricus Fabricius, 1781
as the earliest subsequent designation for
Ascia Meigen, 1822
. Research by Evenhuis (2014: 53) found an earlier designation by Froriep (1825a: 368) of
Syrphus podagricus Fabricius, 1781
.

17 .
Aspistes Meigen , 1818a
: xxxvi , 319 , pl . 11 [ 1818b : xxxvi , 319 , pl . 11 ].

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Aspistes berolinensis Meigen, 1818a
.

TYPE SPECIES :
Aspistes berolinensis Meigen, 1818a
, by monotypy
.
FAMILY: SCATOPSIDAE .

18 .
Asteia Meigen , 1830a : 88
, pl . 59 [ 1830b : vii , 88 , pl . 59 ].

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Asteia amoena Meigen, 1830a
;
Asteia concinna Meigen, 1830a
.

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Asteia amoena Meigen, 1830a
, by subsequent designation (Westwood 1840: 152)
.
FAMILY: ASTEIIDAE .

REMARKS: Blanchard (1840: 629) also designated
Asteia amoena Meigen, 1830a
as type species. However, Westwood’s (1840: 152) designation was earlier. It was published on 1 June 1840 (date recorded by the Entomological Society of London) while Blanchard (1840: 629) was published on 26 December 1840 (see Evenhuis 1997: 434).

EMENDATIONS:
Astia Agassiz, 1846b: 38
(unjustified);
Asteja Lioy, 1864c: 1317
(unjustified).
[ Atalanta ] Meigen , 1800 : 31 .

CURRENT STATUS: Unavailable name; work suppressed for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]); treated under
Clinocera Meigen, 1803
[
teste Yang et al. (2007: 54)
].
FAMILY: EMPIDIDAE .
REMARKS: Subsequently made available by Meigen in Hendel (1908) (see next entry).

19 .
Atalanta Meigen
in Hendel
, 1908 : 60 .
ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES: None.

FIRST INCLUDED SPECIES:
Clinocera nigra Meigen, 1804
(in Coquillett 1910a: 511).

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Clinocera nigra Meigen, 1804
, by subsequent designation (Coquillett 1910a: 511)
.

CURRENT STATUS : Preoccupied by
Atalanta Stål, 1861
;
Atalanta Seeley, 1864
; junior synonym of
Clinocera Meigen, 1803
[
teste Evenhuis & Pape (2017: 25)
].
FAMILY: EMPIDIDAE .

REMARKS:
Atalanta
was originally proposed by Meigen (1800: 31) without included species and later made unavailable by the suppression of the work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hendel (1908: 60) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) and to treat it as a valid name, which makes the name available from that work. Hendel (1908) did not include any species. Coquillett (1910a: 511) was the first to include a species (
Clinocera nigra Meigen, 1804
), which is the type species by subsequent designation.
Clinocera nigra Meigen, 1804
is currently treated in
Clinocera Meigen, 1803
[
teste Yang et al. (2007: 54)
], which makes
Atalanta Meigen
in Hendel, 1908 a junior synonym of
Clinocera Meigen, 1803
.

20 .
Atherix Meigen , 1803 : 271
.

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Rhagio diadema Fabricius, 1775
;
Rhagio cinctus Fabricius, 1787
.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
ICZN Code Art
.
70 . 3 . 2
as
Rhagio ibis Fabricius, 1798
, misidentified as
Rhagio

subSubSection.paragraph:
diadema Fabricius, 1775,
sensu Meigen, 1803
[
teste Sabrosky (1999: 58)
], by subsequent designation (Coquillett 1910a: 511).
FAMILY: ATHERICIDAE .

REMARKS : Earlier designations by Latreille (1810: 443), Westwood (1840: 134), Blanchard in Audouin et al. (1845c: pl. 169), Rondani (1856: 154), and De Galdo (1856: 572) are invalid as they were of species that were not originally included in Meigen (1803).

21 .
Atractocera Meigen , 1803 : 263
.

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Tipula regelationis Linnaeus, 1758
.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
TYPE
SPECIES
:
Tipula regelationis Linnaeus, 1758
, by monotypy [ruled by I.C.Z.N. (1981: 105; Opinion 1174]).

subSubSection.paragraph:
CURRENT STATUS : Junior synonym of
Trichocera Meigen, 1803
[
teste Dahl (1992: 33)
].
FAMILY: TRICHOCERIDAE .

REMARKS: Meigen’s (1803) original description of
Atractocera
included a single species,
Tipula regelationis Linnaeus, 1758
. However, Meigen’s (1804) description of
Atractocera regelationis
appears to be of a simuliid; and Meigen ( in Panzer 1808; 1818a) in fact said he had previously (1803) misidentified
Tipula regelationis ( sensu Meigen, 1803)
and in 1818 described his taxon as his new species
Simulia ornata Meigen, 1818a
. This misidentification of the type species of
Atractocera
was the cause of some confusion and Dahl (1975: 43) submitted an application to the ICZN Commission to designate the true
Tipula regelationis Linnaeus
as the type species, which would then place
Atractocera Meigen, 1803
in synonymy with
Trichocera Meigen, 1803
. Because both

30 .
Calirrhoe Meigen & Hendel
in Hendel
, 1908 : 66 .

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:

CURRENT STATUS: Junior synonym of

[
teste Evenhuis & Pape (2017: 25)
].
FAMILY: TACHINIDAE .

REMARKS:
Calirrhoe
was originally proposed by Meigen (1800: 39) without included species and later made unavailable by the suppression of the work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hendel (1908: 60) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) and to treat it as a valid name, which makes the name available from that work. Because Hendel repeated Meigen’s characters verbatim, Meigen is one of the authors, but Hendel also gave additional characters in his Anmerkung , which makes Hendel a co-author. Hendel (1908) included one species,
Stomoxys siberita Fabricius, 1775
, which is the type species by monotypy.
Stomoxys siberita Fabricius, 1775
is currently treated in
Prosena Le Peletier & Audinet-Serville, 1828
[
teste O’Hara & Cerretti (2016: 47)
], which makes
Calirrhoe Meigen & Hendel
in Hendel, 1908 a junior synonym of
Prosena Le Peletier & Audinet-Serville, 1828
. There are two original spellings of this nominal genus in this work:
Calirrhoe
(page 66) and
Callirrhoe
(page 68).Acting as First Reviser, Evenhuis & Pape (2017: 26) selected
Calirrhoe
as the correct original spelling.

:

REMARKS:
Chlorops Meigen, 1803
was originally proposed without included species. Previous workers [e.g., Coquillett (1910a: 522); Sabrosky (1941: 740; 1999: 85)] have thought the work with the first included species in
Chlorops
was Meigen (1830a: 140–163). However, in this study we have found that in an unsigned review of the work of Fabricius (1805) by Anonymous (1806b: 77) three species (see above) were included in the genus
Chlorops Meigen, 1803
, which represents the earliest inclusion of species in the genus. The ICZN Commission (I.C.Z.N. 1955a: 423 (Opinion 348)], in conserving the name
Chlorops Meigen, 1803
, designated
Musca pumilionis Bjerkander, 1778
as the type species of
Chlorops Meigen, 1803
. This was based on the evidence given by Sabrosky (1941: 740), who believed that
Musca pumilionis Bjerkander, 1788
was one of the first included species (in synonymy with
Musca lineata Fabricius, 1781
) in Meigen (1830a: 140). However, because there is no change in the generic concept since
Musca pumilionis Bjerkander, 1778
and
Musca lineata Fabricius, 1781
are currently considered synonymous [
teste Nartshuk (2012: 26)
], there is no need to apply to the ICZN to correct the type-species designation in Opinion 348.

Meigen (1803: 274) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon and to treat it as a valid name, which makes the name available from that work. Eristalis coemiteriorum de Fab.
, est le type de la première division de ce genre, et le
Chrysogaster elegans , Meig.
, celui de l’autre” [… the
Eristalis coemiteriorum
of Fab., is the type of the first division of this genus, and the
Chrysogaster elegans , Meig.
, that of the other], is invalid because two types are designated for the same genus. Zetterstedt (1843: 816) designated
Musca solstitialis Linnaeus, 1758
[as “
Chrysogaster solstitialis
”] with “

” in questionable synonymy, thus this is also invalid. Coquillett (1910a: 523) designated

coemiteriorum Fabricius
”) and is the earliest subsequent designation for
Chrysogaster Meigen, 1803

Meigen (1803: 274) included the single species
Tabanus caecutiens Linnaeus, 1758
[as “
Tabanus caecutiens Fabr.
”], which is the type species by monotypy.

REMARKS: Cleona was originally proposed by Meigen (1800: 30) without included species and later made unavailable by the suppression of the work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hendel (1908: 59) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) but treated the name in synonymy with
Callimyia Meigen, 1803
; however no species were included in the genus in this work. Coquillett (1910a: 508) was the first to treat the name as valid and thus make the name available, and by including a single species he also designated a type species. Because Coquillett was dealing with the names as given in Hendel (1908), the authorship is attributed to Meigen in Hendel (1908) following ICZN Code Art. 67.7. Coquillett (1910a: 525) was the first to include a species (
Callomyia elegans Meigen, 1804
), which is the type species by subsequent designation.
Callomyia elegans Meigen, 1804
is currently treated in
Callomyia Meigen, 1803
[
teste Sabrosky (1999: 91)
], which makes Cleona Meigen in Hendel, 1908 a junior synonym of

.

REMARKS: An earlier type fixation for

is in Latreille (1810: 442), who designated
Tipula atrata Linnaeus, 1758
. Melville (1960: 27) cited this type designation in his list of proposed genus-group names to be placed on the
Official Index of Rejected and Invalid Generic Names in Zoology
in his proposal regarding the names in Meigen (1800). However, acceptance of this designation would threaten the stability of
Ctenophora Meigen, 1803
by placing it as the senior synonym of
Tanyptera Latreille, 1804
and a new genusgroup name would have to be proposed for species currently treated in the nominate subgenus
Ctenophora Meigen, 1803
(cf. Oosterbroek & Theowald 1992: 59–61 for species involved). An application to the ICZN Commission to set aside designations of type species for
Ctenophora Meigen, 1803
prior to Curtis (1824) seems warranted. See Sabrosky (1999: 101) for further details. NB: Oosterbroek & Theowald (1992: 59) erred in giving the type species for
Ctenophora Meigen, 1803
as
Tipula pectinicornis Linnaeus, 1758
, by subsequent designation by Latreille (1804: 442). A few years earlier, Oosterbroek (1989: 54) gave the type species as
Tipula pectinicornis Linnaeus, 1758
by subsequent designation by Westwood (1840: 128). The designation of the same species in Curtis (1824: pl. 5) was earlier.

[ Diamesa ] Meigen , 1830a : pl . 65 . [ 1830b : x , pl . 65 ].

CURRENT STATUS: Incorrect subsequent spelling of
Lestremia Macquart, 1826a
[
teste Sabrosky (1999: 111)
].
FAMILY: CECIDOMYIIDAE .

REMARKS :
Diamesa
originally appeared in Meigen (1830a: pl. 65). In the text of the same work (Meigen, 1830a: 308), there is a footnote to the effect that Meigen wished to correct the name on the plate from
Diamesa
to
Lestremia Macquart, 1826a
[in Cecidomyiidae ]: “ Der Name Diamesa muss auf der Tafel ausgelöscht und in Lestremia verändert werden, welcher dieser Gattung schon früher von Macquart gegeben wurde, wie mir Herr Wiedemann schreibt. Ich besitze sein Werk nicht .” [The name
Diamesa
on the plate must be deleted and changed to
Lestremia
, which was given to this genus earlier by Macquart, as Mr. Wiedemann writes to me. I do not own his work.] In the Nachtrag to this work, Meigen (1830b: x) also indicated that the name on the plate should be
Lestremia Macquart, 1826a
. Sabrosky (1999) concluded that the 1830a printing of
Diamesa
, because it was corrected in the same work to
Lestremia
[in Cecidomyiidae ], does not preoccupy its later appearance in Meigen in Waltl (1835a: 66), where it is proposed for a new genus to include the species
Diamesa cinerella Meigen
in Waltl, 1835a [in Chironomidae ]. We follow this treatment here. Ashe & O’Connor (2009: 267, 346) treated “ Diamesa ” in Meigen (1830a) as an unavailable name published as a junior synonym (ICZN Code Art. 11.6). It may seem strange to consider two entirely different words as spellings of the same name rather than different names for the same species (i.e., as synonyms), and arguments may be raised for both solutions. We consider the present solution to be fully justified, and it has the advantage of avoiding any risk that
Diamesa
of Meigen (1830a) [ Cecidomyiidae ] may possibly preoccupy
Diamesa
of Meigen in Waltl (1835a) [ Chironomidae ], which would happen given a subsequent pre-1961 usage of the former as valid.

68 .
Diamesa Meigen in Waltl
, 1835a : 66 [ Meigen , 1838 : 12 ].

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Diamesa cinerella Meigen
in Waltl, 1835a.

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Diamesa cinerella Meigen
in Waltl, 1835a, by monotypy
.
FAMILY: CHIRONOMIDAE .

REMARKS: Long thought to be made available first in Meigen (1838), Sabrosky (1999: 111) attempted to present some clarity to the confusion that existed over the date of availability of
Diamesa Meigen.
Diamesa
was used four times by Meigen: first for a cecidomyiid (Meigen 1830a: pl. 65), and then three times for a chironomid (Meigen in Waltl, 1835a: 66; Meigen in Waltl, 1837: 283; Meigen 1838: 12). Wiedemann had apparently seen the plates Meigen had prepared before the text was completed and let him know that the fly he had thought was a new genus was actually the cecidomyiid
Lestremia Macquart, 1826a
. Meigen explained in his footnote (Meigen 1830a: 308) that he made the mistake as he did not have a copy of Macquart (1826a). As Meigen could not correct the plate, he changed
Diamesa
in the text to that work (Meigen 1830a: 308) to
Lestremia Macquart, 1826a
.
Diamesa Meigen, 1830a
is treated here as an incorrect subsequent spelling of
Lestremia Macquart, 1826a
, thus
Diamesa Meigen
in Waltl, 1835a in Chironomidae is not preoccupied.

[ Platystomatidae ]. As pointed out in Rozkošný (1984: 131), there is no need for ICZN action because Meigen’s (1803: 277) listing of “

REMARKS: Meigen (1800: 24) originally proposed
Dionaea
without included species and it was later made unavailable by the suppression of the work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hendel (1908: 54) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) and treated it as a valid name, but now with the spelling Dionnaea , which makes the name available from that work with Meigen & Hendel as co-authors. Hendel (1908) included two species:
Empis borealis Linnaeus, 1758
and
Empis platyptera Panzer, 1794
. Coquillett (1910a: 534) designated
Empis platyptera Panzer, 1794
, which is the type species by subsequent designation.
Empis platyptera Panzer, 1794
is currently treated in
Rhamphomyia Meigen, 1822
[
teste Yang et al . (2007: 149)
], which makes Dionnaea Meigen in Hendel, 1908 a junior synonym of
Rhamphomyia Meigen, 1822
. Hendel (1908: 54) misspelled Meigen’s genus-group name but, as this is the first availability of the name, this is the correct original spelling. Coquillett (1910a: 534) followed Hendel’s (1908) spelling of the genus-group name when designating a type for it.

as a senior synonym of
Molophilus Curtis, 1833a
and a new genus-group name would then be needed for species currently placed in

. See, e.g., Stone (1941: 407) for further details. In a proposal to the ICZN Commission on how to deal with the Meigen (1800) names, Melville (1960: 30–31) pointed out these and other particulars with regard to usage of
Erioptera Meigen, 1803
and
Molophilus Curtis, 1833a
, requesting specialists to say whether they wished the Plenary Powers to be used to stabilize usage. However, due to the ICZN vote resulting in Opinion 678 (I.C.Z.N. 1963: 339), the request to the ICZN to resolve
Erioptera
and
Molophilus
seems to have not been taken up by anyone. Despite the ICZN ruling on the Meigen (1800) names, the problem described above remains and an application to the ICZN may be warranted.

(1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hendel (1908: 47) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) but treated the name in synonymy with
Macrocera Meigen, 1803
; however no species were included in the genus in this work. Hendel’s (1908) single species, given as “

?”, is tentatively identified and, as such, is not allowed under ICZN Code Article 67.2.5. Coquillett (1910a: 508) was the first to treat the name as valid and designated a type species,
Macrocera lutea Meigen, 1804
, thus making the name available. Because Coquillett was dealing with the names as given in Hendel (1908), the authorship is attributed as Meigen in Hendel (1908).
Macrocera lutea Meigen, 1804
is currently treated in
Macrocera Meigen, 1803
[
teste Evenhuis (2006: 31)
], which makes
Euphrosyne Meigen
in Hendel, 1908 as a junior synonym of
Macrocera Meigen, 1803
.

Fungivora
was originally proposed by Meigen (1800: 16) without included species and later made unavailable by the suppression of the work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hendel (1908: 48) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) and to treat it as a valid name, which makes the name available from that work with Meigen as author. Hendel (1908) included two nominal species. Coquillett (1910a: 545) designated the second of these two,
Tipula agarici Villers, 1789
, which is the type species by subsequent designation.
Tipula agarici Villers, 1789
is currently treated in
Mycetophila Meigen, 1803
[
teste Sabrosky (1999: 140)

CURRENT STATUS : Senior synonym of

[
teste Ribeiro & Santos (2016: 85)
].
FAMILY: LIMONIIDAE .

REMARKS:
Furcomyia Meigen, 1818a
and
Dicranomyia Stephens, 1829c
have been considered synonymous for more than 100 years (e.g., at least as long ago as Coquillett 1910: 546).
Furcomyia Meigen, 1818a
was originally proposed in synonymy (with
Limonia Meigen, 1803
) but made available by subsequent usage as a valid name in Macquart (1826a: 144). We follow previous catalogs [e.g., Savchenko et al . (1992: 332), Ribeiro & Santos (2016: 85), etc.] in treating the younger
Dicranomyia Stephens, 1829c
as the valid name for species in this genus. Acceptance of the older but less used name would threaten the stability of nomenclature and taxonomy.
Furcomyia Meigen, 1818a
cannot be a declared nomen oblitum because it was used as a valid name after 1899 (e.g., Coquillett 1910a: 546, Alexander 1913: 487). An application to the ICZN is warranted to suppress
Furcomyia Meigen, 1818a
in favor of
Dicranomyia Stephens, 1829c
.

REMARKS: Meigen (1818a: 209) stated that he was using
Nematocera Meigen, 1818a
in place of
Hexatoma Latreille, 1809
and that he could not accept
Hexatoma Latreille, 1809
because
Heptatoma Meigen, 1803
(in Tabanidae ) needed to be replaced with a better name (
Hexatoma
): “ Ich konnte den von Latreille eingeführten Namen Hexatoma nicht annehmen, weil die zu den Tabanen gehörige Gattung Heptatoma nothwendig in Hexatoma verändert werden muss .” [I could not accept the name
Hexatoma
introduced by Latreille, because the tabanid genus
Heptatoma
necessarily must be changed into
Hexatoma .
] In Meigen (1820: 83) he made the substitution of
Hexatoma
for
Heptatoma
again and remarked: “
In meiner Klassifikation heisst diese Gattung
Heptatoma , welcher Name nach-gehends von andern Schriftstellern angenommen wurde. Da er aber auf die Beobachtung eines fehlerhaften Originals sich gründete, so musste er nothwendig umgeandert werden. Die Gattung
Hexatoma Latr.
gehöret zur Familie der Tipularien und heitzt bei mir Nematocera .” [In my classification, I call this genus
Heptatoma
, which name was later adopted by other writers. But since it was founded on a faulty original observation, it necessarily had to be changed. The genus
Hexatoma Latr.
belongs to the family of the Tipularien and is called
Nematocera
by me.] Meigen was apparently under the impression that a simple change of his own name would take on the date of his original name (1803; and thus maintaining priority over
Hexatoma Latreille, 1809
) and not have the actual date of its replacement.
EMENDATIONS: Exatoma Rondani, 1856: 170 (unjustified).

teste
this work ].

Hydropota
but changed the name to

in his 1803 work and in the text to the 1804 work, but could not change the engraved plate. We here treat this as an incorrect subsequent spelling of

Robineau- Desvoidy, 1830 using the spelling “
Hylemyia
” is
Hylemyia Macquart (1835: 315)
as an unjustified emendation (Evenhuis et al. 2016: 73). Because of the equivocal nature of the usage of the name, we invoke ICZN Code Art. 33.5 and treat all usages of
Hylemyia
in Meigen (1838) as incorrect subsequent spellings.

REMARKS:
Lampetia
was originally proposed by Meigen (1800: 34) without included species and later made unavailable by the suppression of the work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hendel (1908: 62) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) and treated it as a valid name, which makes the name available from that work with Meigen as author. Hendel (1908) included two nominal species:
Syrphus equestris Fabricius, 1794
and
Syrphus clavipes Fabricius, 1781
[as “...
curvipes
F.”]. Coquillett (1910a: 557) selected
Syrphus clavipes Fabricius, 1781
, which is the type species by subsequent designation.
Syrphus clavipes Fabricius, 1781
is currently treated in
Merodon Meigen, 1803
[
teste Peck (1988: 165)
], which makes
Lampetia Meigen
in Hendel, 1908 a junior synonym of
Merodon Meigen, 1803
.

Musca grossa Linnaeus, 1758

.

:

REMARKS : Meigen (1803: 275) listed the included species as “
Mulio ichneumoneus Fabr.
s.
Musca aristata Panz.
” The lower case “s.” indicates the Latin “ seu ” or “ sive ” [both = “or”]. As Sabrosky (1999: 182) indicated, there is confusion over whether one or two species are included. We feel the most prudent course of action is to assume two originally included species, which thus requires a subsequent designation. Latreille (1810: 444) designated
Musca ichneumonea Linnaeus, 1758
and is the earliest subsequent designation, the acceptance of which does not change the concept of the genus.

.

.

].

and
Salticella Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
were both published in the same year, Meigen (1830a) has been dated as published on 3 October 1830 (from dating research conducted during this study; see References below) while Robineau-Desvoidy (1830) was published on 6 June 1830 (
teste Evenhuis et al . 2010
), thus
Salticella
is the older name.
[Lycoria] Meigen , 1800 : 17 .

CURRENT STATUS: Unavailable name; work suppressed for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]); treated under
Sciara Meigen, 1803
[
teste Sabrosky (1999: 183)
].
FAMILY: SCIARIDAE .
REMARKS: Subsequently made available by Latreille (1802: 424) [see Evenhuis & Pape (2017: 41)].

147 .
Macrocera Meigen , 1803 : 261
.
ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES: None.

FIRST INCLUDED SPECIES:
Macrocera lutea Meigen, 1804
;
Macrocera fasciata Meigen, 1804
;
Macrocera hybrida Meigen, 1804
;
Tipula incarnata Linnaeus, 1767
(as “
Mac. incarnata
”; with
Tipula longicornis Linnaeus, 1758
in synonymy) (in Meigen 1804: 46–48).

TYPE SPECIES :
Macrocera lutea Meigen, 1804
, by subsequent designation (Guérin 1826a: 7)
.
FAMILY: KEROPLATIDAE .

REMARKS: Meigen (1803: 261) included the single species-group name “
Tipula longicornis
?”. Because this was doubtfully included, it cannot be considered an originally included species. The first species included in
Macrocera
were the four species listed in Meigen (1804: 46–47). From these, Guérin (1826a: 7) designated
Macrocera lutea Meigen, 1804
as the type species of
Macrocera
. Melville (1960) and Evenhuis (2006) recorded Curtis (1837a: pl. 637) as having subsequently designated
Macrocera lutea Meigen, 1804
for
Macrocera Meigen, 1803
, but this was later. Evenhuis (2006: 128) noted that the fourth included species in Meigen (1804: 47) [
Tipula incarnata Linnaeus, 1767
] was probably a cecidomyiid, but no type specimen exists in the Linnaean Collection in London.

148 .
Macrochira Meigen , 1803 : 278
.

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:

.

Musca manicata Fabricius, 1794
, by monotypy
.

CURRENT STATUS: Junior synonym of
Ochthera Latreille, 1802
[
teste Mathis & Zatwarnicki (1995: 144)
].
FAMILY: EPHYDRIDAE .

149 .
Macropeza Meigen , 1818a
: xxxiv , 87 , pl . 3 [ 1818b : xxxiv , 87 , pl . 3 ].

.

Macropeza albitarsis Meigen, 1818a
, by monotypy
.
FAMILY: CERATOPOGONIDAE .

150 .
Mallota Meigen , 1822
: x , 377 , pl . 32 .

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:

;
Syrphus megilliformis Fallén, 1817a
;
Syrphus fuciformis Fabricius, 1794
.

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Syrphus fuciformis Fabricius, 1794
, by subsequent designation (Rondani 1845: 452). CURRENT STATUS : Valid genus [
teste Peck (1988: 199)
]. FAMILY: SYRPHIDAE . REMARKS : Blanchard in Audouin et al . (1845b: pl. 174) designated the same type species as Rondani (1845), but dating research in this study shows Rondani (1845) [ 18 January ] to have priority over Audouin et al . (1845b) [October].

151 .
Marginomyia Meigen , 1818a : 147
[ 1818b : 147 ].

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Limnobia cinerascens Meigen, 1818a
(with “
Marginomyia cinerea ” Megerle
[
nomen nudum
] in synonymy).

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Limnobia cinerascens Meigen, 1818a
(with “
Marginomyia cinerea ” Megerle
[
nomen nudum
] in synonymy), by monotypy.

CURRENT STATUS : Senior synonym of
Dicranoptycha Osten Sacken, 1860
[
teste Savchenko et al . (1992: 269)
].
FAMILY: LIMONIIDAE .

REMARKS:
Marginomyia Meigen, 1818a
was originally proposed in synonymy (with
Limnobia Meigen, 1818a
) but was made available by subsequent usage as a valid name (in Coquillett 1910a: 565) [in contrast to the statement in Savchenko et al . (1992: 269) and Podenas et al . (2015: 259)].
Marginomyia Meigen, 1818a
is currently treated as a synonym of
Dicranoptycha Osten Sacken, 1860
( e.g. , Savchenko 1992: 269; Podenas et al . (2015: 259). Acceptance of priority would upset the stability of nomenclature and taxonomy by accepting a little-used name (
Marginomyia
) over a widely used name (
Dicranoptycha
). Application to the ICZN may be warranted to either suppress
Marginomyia Meigen, 1818a
for the purposes of the Principle of Priority or to put it into reversed precedence with
Dicranoptycha Osten Sacken, 1860
in order to conserve
Dicranoptycha Osten Sacken, 1860
.

152 .
Medeterus Meigen , 1824
: x , 59 , pl . 35 .

; junior synonym of
Medetera Fischer von Waldheim, 1819
[
teste Yang et al . (2006: 269)
].
FAMILY: DOLICHOPODIDAE .
REMARKS: Name made available as an emendation by virtue of the original and changed spellings printed in the same work and the changed spelling being adopted.

Melania Meigen , 1838 : 274
.

;

;
Phorophylla palpalis Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
(as “
Sericocera palp
.—Id. Buff. II. 167, 4.”).

TYPE
SPECIES
:

, by subsequent designation (Rondani 1856: 89)
.

;
Melania Perry, 1811
;
Melania Sodovsky, 1837
; junior synonym of

[

].

Melanophora Meigen , 1803 : 279
.

[ Melusina ] Meigen , 1800 : 19 .
CURRENT STATUS: Unavailable name; work suppressed for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of

I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]); treated under
Trichocera Meigen, 1803
[
teste Dahl (1992: 33)
].
FAMILY: TRICHOCERIDAE .
REMARKS: Subsequently made available by Meigen in Hendel (1908) (see next entry).

155 .
Melusina Meigen
in Hendel
, 1908 : 50 .

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Tipula regelationis Linnaeus, 1758
.

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Tipula regelationis Linnaeus, 1758
, by monotypy
.

CURRENT STATUS : Preoccupied by
Melusina Stål, 1867
;
Melusina Haeckel, 1880
; junior synonym of
Trichocera Meigen, 1803
[
teste Evenhuis & Pape (2017: 41)
].
FAMILY: TRICHOCERIDAE .

REMARKS:
Melusina
was originally proposed by Meigen (1800: 19) without included species and later made unavailable by the suppression of the work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hendel (1908: 50) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) and to treat it as a valid name, which makes the name available from that work with Meigen as author. Hendel (1908) included a single species:
Tipula regelationis Linnaeus, 1758
, which is the type species by monotypy.
Tipula regelationis Linnaeus, 1758
is currently treated in
Trichocera Meigen, 1803
[
teste Dahl (1992: 33)
], which makes
Melusina Meigen
in Hendel, 1908 a junior synonym of
Trichocera Meigen, 1803
. In attempting to decipher Meigen’s (1800) names, Hendel (1908: 50) concluded that
Melusina
was synonymous with
Atractocera Meigen, 1803
, for which Meigen had included the single species “
Tipula regelationis ” (Meigen, 1803: 263)
.
Atractocera Meigen, 1803
was later synonymized with
Simulium Meigen, 1803
when Meigen (1818a) placed
Tipula regelationis Linnaeus, 1758
as a synonym of
Simulia ornata Meigen, 1818a
in the genus
Simulium Meigen, 1803
. The ICZN Commission (I.C.Z.N. 1981: 105 [Opinion 1174]) solved the problem by determining that
Tipula regelationis Linnaeus, 1758
was the type of
Atractocera Meigen, 1803
and that
Atractocera Meigen, 1803
was an invalid junior synonym of
Trichocera Meigen, 1803
.

156 .
Merodon Meigen , 1803 : 274
.

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Syrphus equestris Fabricius, 1794
;
Syrphus clavipes Fabricius, 1781
(as “
Syrphus ...
curvipes Fabr.
”).

TYPE SPECIES :
Syrphus clavipes Fabricius, 1794
, by subsequent designation (Guérin 1826b: 446)
.
FAMILY: SYRPHIDAE .

REMARKS: Meigen erred in the spelling of the second included species as Fabricius did not describe a “
Syrphus curvipes
”. However, Gmelin (1790: 2871) listed the name
Syrphus curvipes
[which is essentially a replacement name by Gmelin for
Syrphus clavipes Fabricius, 1794
] but gave no other Fabrician name and only gave the citation “ Fabr. sp. ins. 2, p. 427. n. 29. mant. ins. 2. p. 337. n. 33 ”; which might have confused Meigen into believing
Syrphus curvipes
was a Fabrician name. Melville (1960: 28), Peck (1988: 165), and Thompson (2008) gave the typification as
Syrphus clavipes Fabricius, 1794
, by subsequent designation by Westwood (1840: 137). Guérin’s (1826b) designation is of the same nominal species and was earlier.

157 .
Meromyza Meigen , 1830a : 163
, pl . 61 [ 1830b : viii , 163 , pl . 61 ].

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:

;
Meromyza variegata Meigen, 1830a
;
Musca saltatrix Linnaeus, 1760
(with

and

in synonymy).

TYPE
SPECIES
:

, by subsequent designation (Macquart 1835: 589)
.

;

(with

,

,

, and
Musca bombyl- oides or bom- byloides
Sulzer, 1776 in synonymy).

TYPE SPECIES :
Musca meridiana Linnaeus, 1758
, by subsequent designation (
Stephens in Richardson
1838: 116)
.
FAMILY: MUSCIDAE .

REMARKS: Previous catalogs (e.g., Pont 1986a: 84; Sabrosky 1999: 193) gave the type species for this genusgroup name as
Musca meridiana Linnaeus, 1758
, by subsequent designation by Westwood (1840: 141), but Evenhuis (2010) found a designation of the same species by Stephens in Richardson (1838: 116), which was earlier.

159 .
Metopia Meigen , 1803 : 280
.

SPECIES :

”) [preoccupied by

; =

], by monotypy.

Microcera Meigen , 1803 : 273
.

(in Coquillett 1910a: 569).

TYPE
SPECIES :

, by subsequent designation (Coquillett 1910a: 569). CURRENT STATUS: Junior synonym of
Pipunculus Latreille, 1802
[
teste De Meyer (1996: 21)
].
FAMILY: PIPUNCULIDAE .

161 .
Microdon Meigen , 1803 : 275
.

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Musca mutabilis Linnaeus, 1758
(as “
Mulio mutabilis Fabr.
”).

TYPE
SPECIES :
Musca mutabilis Linnaeus, 1758
(as “
Mulio mutabilis Fabr.
”), by monotypy.
FAMILY: SYRPHIDAE .
[ Micropalpus ] Meigen , 1838 : ix .

CURRENT STATUS: Incorrect subsequent spelling of
Micropalpis Macquart, 1834b
or subsequent usage of
Micropalpus Macquart, 1835
.
FAMILY: TACHINIDAE .
REMARKS: Criteria to make this name available were not found to be fulfilled in this work.

162 .
Micropeza Meigen , 1803 : 276
.

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:

(as “
Musca corrigiolata Fabr.
”).

TYPE
SPECIES :
Musca corrigiolata Linnaeus, 1767
(as “
Musca corrigiolata Fabr.
”), by monotypy.
FAMILY: MICROPEZIDAE .
[Midas] Meigen , 1826 : vi [ 1830a : pl . 66 ; 1830b : pl . 66 ].

CURRENT STATUS: Incorrect subsequent spelling of
Mydas Fabricius, 1794
or subsequent usage of
Midas Latreille, 1797
.
FAMILY: MYDIDAE .

REMARKS: Although this name might be construed as being made available as an emendation by virtue of similar spelling changes in two or more names from “y” to “i” in the same work, the earliest mention of
Mydas Fabricius, 1794
that we have found using the spelling “
Midas
” is
Midas Latreille, 1797
, as an unjustified emendation [
teste Evenhuis & Pont 2013: 31
]. Because of the equivocal nature of the usage of the name, we invoke ICZN Code Article 33.5 and treat all usages of “ Midas ” in Meigen (1826, 1830a, 1830b) as incorrect subsequent spellings of
Mydas Fabricius, 1794
.

Milichia Meigen , 1830a : 131

.

TYPE
SPECIES
:

.
FAMILY: MILICHIIDAE .

Miltogramma Meigen , 1803 : 280
.

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Miltogramma punctata Meigen, 1824
, by subsequent designation (Curtis 1834b: pl. 529)
.
FAMILY: SARCOPHAGIDAE .
EMENDATIONS : Myltogramma Rondani, 1868: 586 (unjustified).

165 .
Mima Meigen , 1820 : 174
.

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Anthrax phaeoptera Meigen, 1820
(as “
Anthr. phaeoptera
. Wied.” with “
Mima titanus ” Megerle
[
nomen nudum
] in synonymy).

TYPE
SPECIES :
Anthrax phaeoptera Meigen, 1820
(as “
Anthr. phaeoptera
. Wied.” with “
Mima titanus ” Megerle
[
nomen nudum
] in synonymy), by monotypy.

CURRENT STATUS : Senior synonym of
Heteralonia Rondani, 1863
[
teste Evenhuis & Greathead (2015: 398)
].
FAMILY: BOMBYLIIDAE .

REMARKS:
Mima Meigen, 1820
was originally proposed in synonymy (with
Anthrax Scopoli, 1763
) and first made available by subsequent usage as valid name in Coquillett (1910a: 570). Evenhuis & Greathead (2015: 398) gave the method of typification as by subsequent designation by Coquillett (1910a: 570). Since only one valid species (
Anthrax phaeoptera Meigen, 1820
) was originally included [with “
Mima titanus
” (
nomen nudum
) in synonymy], the typification of
Mima
is by monotypy. Acceptance of the priority of
Mima Meigen, 1820
would upset the stability of nomenclature and taxonomy of both
Heteralonia Rondani, 1863
and
Homolonia Bowden, 1975
(currently a subgenus of
Heteralonia Rondani, 1863
). Being older than
Heteralonia Rondani, 1863
and all its nominal subgenera,
Mima Meigen, 1820
would both replace
Heteralonia
as the valid name for the genus and become the nominate subgenus. Application to the ICZN to conserve
Heteralonia Rondani, 1863
seems warranted.

166 .
Murana Meigen , 1824 : 223
.

(as “

. Meg.”; with “

[

] in synonymy).

SPECIES
:

(as “
Tr. alpina
. Meg.”; with “
Murana alpina ” Megerle
[
nomen nudum
] in synonymy), by monotypy.

[
teste Herting & Dely-Draskovits (1993: 255)
].
FAMILY: TACHINIDAE .

REMARKS:
Murana Meigen, 1824
was originally proposed in synonymy (with
Trixa Meigen, 1822
) and made available by subsequent usage as a valid name in Townsend (1938: 239).
[ Musidora ] Meigen , 1800 : 30 .

CURRENT STATUS: Unavailable name; work suppressed for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]); treated under
Lonchoptera Meigen, 1803
[
teste Andersson (1991: 140)
].
FAMILY: LONCHOPTERIDAE .
REMARKS: Subsequently made available by Meigen in Hendel (1908) (see next entry).

167 .
Musidora Meigen
in Hendel
, 1908 : 59 .
ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES: None.

FIRST INCLUDED SPECIES:
Lonchoptera lutea Meigen
in Panzer, 1809 (in Coquillett 1910b: 377).

TYPE SPECIES :
Lonchoptera lutea Meigen
in Panzer, 1809, by subsequent designation (Coquillett 1910b: 377)
.

CURRENT STATUS : Junior synonym of
Lonchoptera Meigen, 1803
[
teste Evenhuis & Pape (2017: 42)
].
FAMILY: LONCHOPTERIDAE .

REMARKS:
Musidora
was originally proposed by Meigen (1800: 30) without included species and later made unavailable by the suppression of the work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hendel (1908: 59) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) and to treat it as a valid name, which makes the name available from that work with Meigen as author. Hendel (1908) did not include any species. Coquillett (1910b: 377) was the first to include a species:
Lonchoptera lutea Meigen
in Panzer, 1809, which is the type species by subsequent designation.
Lonchoptera lutea Meigen
in Panzer, 1809 is currently treated in
Lonchoptera Meigen, 1803
[
teste Andersson (1991: 140)
], which makes
Musidora Meigen
in Hendel, 1908 a junior synonym of
Lonchoptera Meigen, 1803
. Stone (1941: 412) missed Coquillett’s (1910b) paper and unnecessarily designated the same type species.
[Mycethophila] Meigen , 1830a : 296 [ 1830b : 296 ].

CURRENT STATUS: Incorrect subsequent spelling of
Mycetophila Meigen, 1803
.
FAMILY: MYCETOPHILIDAE .
REMARKS: Criteria for making this name available as an emendation were not found to be fulfilled in these works.

. Meg.”; with “

[

] in synonymy);

.

, by subsequent designation (

, 169 (unjustified).

.

;

.

;

.

SPECIES :

(as “
Hexatoma bicolor
”), by subsequent designation (Stephens in Richardson 1836: 470).

[

].

REMARKS: Oosterbroek in Savchenko et al . (1992: 237), believing no previous designation had been made for
Nematocera
, designated
Nematocera bicolor Meigen, 1818a
as type species. Evenhuis (2010) discovered the designation of

by Stephens in Richardson (1836). Westwood (1840: 128) designated

and Rondani (1856: 184) also designated

CURRENT STATUS: Incorrect subsequent spelling of
Nemestrinus Latreille, 1802
or subsequent usage of
Nemestrina Latreille, 1809
.
FAMILY: NEMESTRINIDAE .

REMARKS: Although this name might be construed as being made available as an emendation by virtue of similar spelling changes in two or more names from “us” to “a” in the same work, the earliest mention of
Nemestrinus Latreille, 1802
that we have found using the spelling “
Nemestrina
” is
Nemestrina Latreille, 1809: 307
as an unjustified emendation [
teste Evenhuis & Pont (2013: 75)
]. Because of the equivocal nature of the usage of the name in these works, we invoke ICZN Code Article 33.5 and treat all usages of “ Nemestrina ” in Meigen in the above listed works as incorrect subsequent spellings of
Nemestrinus Latreille, 1802
.
[Nemorea] Meigen , 1838 : ix , 221 .

.

.

.

, by monotypy
.

172 .

.

(with “

[
nomen nudum
] in synonymy).

SPECIES :
Atherix maculata Meigen, 1804
(with “
Nodutis maculata ” Megerle
[
nomen nudum
] in synonymy) [=
Rhagio ibis Fabricius, 1798
], by monotypy.

Atherix Meigen, 1803
[
teste Nagatomi (1958: 48)
].
FAMILY: ATHERICIDAE .

REMARKS: This name was originally proposed in synonymy with
Atherix Meigen, 1803
and made available by subsequent usage by Loew (1862: 230) who treated it as a valid name (a senior synonym of
Ibisia Rondani, 1856
).
Nodutis
is not listed in any recent regional catalog [but it is listed in synonymy in the older Kertész (1908: 299) world catalog]. Other than Loew (1862), works that we have found that list this name [e.g., Stephens (1829c: 270), Abl (1855: 420), Kertész (1908: 299), Coquillett (1910a: 576), Lindner (1924: 8), Leonard (1930: 81) all treat it in synonymy with
Atherix Meigen, 1803
. The last worker we have found to do so was Nagatomi (1958: 48), whom we follow here.
[ Noeza ] Meigen , 1800 : 27 .

CURRENT STATUS: Unavailable name; work suppressed for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]); treated under
Hybos Meigen, 1803
[
teste Yang et al . (2007: 287)
].

TYPE

”), by subsequent designation (Westwood 1840: 133); fixed by action of I.C.Z.N. (2014d: 269 [Opinion 2349]).
FAMILY: HYBOTIDAE .

REMARKS : There are two original spellings for this nominal genus in Meigen (1820):
Ocydromia
(p. 351) and Ocydromya (p. 352). By subsequent usage by the same author (ICZN Code Article 24.2.4), Meigen (1830a: 334) acted as First Reviser and selected
Ocydromia
as the correct original spelling. Previous catalogs (e.g., Chvála & Kovalev 1986: 182; Yang et al. 2007: 333) have given the typification of this genus-group name as
Empis glabricula Fallén, 1816b
, by subsequent designation by Westwood (1840: 133). However, Evenhuis (2010) discovered an earlier designation of
Ocydromia ruficollis Meigen, 1820
by Stephens in Richardson (1836). Acceptance of this earlier designation would disrupt the stability of nomenclature and taxonomy of
Ocydromia
as it would place it as a senior synonym of
Leptopeza Macquart, 1828
and would require
Eucinesia Gistel, 1848
to be installed as the valid name for the species currently treated in
Ocydromia
. Application to the ICZN to suppress the designation of
Ocydromia ruficollis Meigen, 1820
by Stephens in Richardson (1838) to conserve the current generic concept of
Ocydromia Meigen, 1820
was submitted (Evenhuis & Sinclair 2012b). The ICZN Commission [I.C.Z.N. 2014d: 269 (Opinion 2349)] voted in favor of conserving the current generic concept of
Ocydromia Meigen, 1820
by setting aside all type fixations prior to that by Westwood (1840: 133).

EMENDATIONS :
Ocydromyia Macquart, 1823: 145
(unjustified).

.

was originally proposed by Meigen (1800: 35) without included species and later made unavailable by the suppression of the work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. Hendel (1908: 63) gave characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) and treated it as a valid name, which makes the name available from that work with Meigen as author. Hendel (1908) did not include species in the main portion of his work, but in a footnote on page 67, he quoted Bezzi ( in litt .), who considered that

[as “
Criorrhina ruficauda
”] can be an included species, thinking that

might be the same as Meigen’s (1803) “73.
Heliophilus

[

(1999: 237], which makes
Penthesilea Meigen
in Hendel, 1908 a junior synonym of
Blera Billberg, 1820
. Coquillett (1910a: 586), unaware of the inclusion of a species in the footnote, designated
Syrphus asilicus Fallén, 1816d
. This invalid designation was thought by many workers to be the first inclusion of a species, and they accordingly put
Penthesilea
in synonymy with
Criorhina Meigen, 1803
. Sabrosky (1999: 237) noted Bezzi’s first included species and was the first to treat
Penthesilea
under
Blera Billberg, 1820
.

as type species, but Coquillett (1903: 256) designated
Empis platyptera Panzer, 1794
as type species and was earlier. However,
Empis platyptera Panzer, 1794
is the type species by absolute tautonymy, which is a method of fixation possible only in the original publication (ICZN Code Article 68.4), and which therefore has precedence over a subsequent designation. However, acceptance of
Empis platyptera Panzer, 1794
as type species would cause instability of nomenclature by placing the lesser-known name Platyptera Meigen, 1803 as a senior synonym of the well-known genus
Rhamphomyia Meigen, 1822
. Application to the ICZN Commission to conserve
Rhamphomyia
by setting aside all typifications prior to Melander (1928) seems warranted.

REMARKS:
Podoctria Meigen, 1820
was proposed in synonymy (with
Dasypogon Meigen, 1803
) and made available by subsequent usage as a valid name in Coquillett (1910a: 593). He designated
Dasypogon vitripennis Meigen, 1820
as the type species; however, Coquillett’s (1910) designation is invalid since it is of a species that was not originally included. We select
Dasypogon priscus Meigen, 1820
, the second of the five included species in Meigen (1820) as the type species by present designation . Doing so puts
Podoctria Meigen, 1820
in synonymy with
Holopogon Loew, 1847
. Acceptance of priority of
Podoctria
would cause instability of nomenclature and taxonomy of the well-known genus
Holopogon
. Application to the ICZN to either suppress
Podoctria Meigen, 1820
for the purposes of the Principle of Priority or to put it into reversed precedence with
Holopogon Loew, 1847
in order to conserve the latter seems warranted. [NB: designation of any one of the five originally included species in Meigen (1820) puts
Podoctria
in synonymy with either
Holopogon Loew, 1847
or
Leptarthrus Stephens, 1829c
so an application would seem to be warranted in any case.]

210 .
Psilopus Meigen , 1824
: x , 35 , pl . 34 .

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Dolichopus platypterus Fabricius, 1805
, by subsequent designation (Westwood 1840: 134)
.

CURRENT STATUS : Preoccupied by
Psilopus Poli, 1795
; senior (but invalid) synonym of
Sciapus Zeller, 1842
[
teste Yang et al. (2006: 442)
].
FAMILY: DOLICHOPODIDAE .

REMARKS : Sherborn (1902: 781) treated
Psilopus Poli, 1795
as a non-taxonomic name: “a generic [= non-taxonomic] term applied to the fleshy parts of certain Chamae [= the genus
Chama
]”. Verrall (1907), no doubt following Sherborn’s lead, concluded “It is now stated that Poli’s name of 1795 was not used in a generic [= nomenclatural] sense.” If these statements were true, then
Psilopus
of Poli (1795) was not a proposal of a new genus, but a morphological term that does not preoccupy
Psilopus Meigen, 1824
. This would result in
Psilopus Meigen, 1824
being the oldest available name for species currently treated in
Sciapus Zeller, 1842
. Collin (1940: 261) discussed the status of the Poli (1795) name and concluded that Poli (1795) proposed
Psilopus
as a genus-group name and not a morphological term. However, it might not be as simple as that. Poli’s (1795: 112) introduction to the groups within
Chama
stated: “ ... Mollusca Chamis circumclusa ad tria Genera referenda esse statuimus; ad Psilopum
nimirum , ad
Glossum, et ad Limnaeum .” [... the molluscan
Chama
can be circumscribed in three groups; as
Psilopus
namely, to Glossum , and to
Limnaeum
]. He then goes on to list the three named ‘groups’ giving characters for each. Collin (1940) interpreted Poli (1795) as splitting
Chama
into three genera and not using the name
Chama
again. However, this seems not to be the case. His plates indicate clearly that he was using
Chama
, but in contrast did not use the three “groups” as genus-group names anywhere else in his work (e.g., there is a pl. 23, fig. 20 referenced under “
Psilopus
” in the main narrative [Poli (1795: 112)] but the species listed in the explanation to that plate and figure (Poli, 1795: liii) is
Chama gryphoides
and not
Psilopus
).
Psilopus Meigen, 1824
had been used by dipterists as an available genus-group name for new species up until 1929. Until the matter of the true origin of Poli’s (1795)
Psilopus
can be concluded, we follow Collin (1940) in treating
Psilopus Poli, 1795
as an available name, which results in
Psilopus Meigen, 1824
being preoccupied.

as a senior synonym of the genus-group name Pararhamphomyia Frey, 1922 (currently a subgenus in Rham- phomyia ). Application to suppress the designation by Guérin (1828) was submitted to the ICZN Commission (Barták & Sinclair 2003), which voted in favor, setting aside all type designation prior to Curtis (1834: pl. 517) (I.C.Z.N. 2005: 114 [Opinion 2117]).

Hendel (1908) did not include any species. Coquillett (1910a: 602) was the first to include a species:

The fact that Hendel (1908) only treated as valid those names in boldface and Salpyga was not in boldface was missed. A search of the literature during this study did not find any subsequent usage of this name as valid before 1961 and thus it remains unavailable.

220 .
Sarcophaga Meigen , 1824 : 305
.
ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES: None.

TYPE
SPECIES
:

, by subsequent designation (Partington 1837: 607)
.

CURRENT STATUS : Junior synonym of
Sarcophaga Swinderen, 1822
; valid genus [
teste Pape (1996: 294)
].
FAMILY: SARCOPHAGIDAE .

REMARKS . Meigen (1824: 305) tentatively included
Tachina rubricosa Meigen, 1824
in
Sarcophaga
, but this does not comply with ICZN Code Article 67.2.5 and Meigen (1826) is the first author to make a valid inclusion of nominal species.
Sarcophaga Meigen, 1824: 305
has not been recognized before as a Code -compliant proposal, which means that
Sarcophaga
of Meigen (1826: 14) becomes a subsequent usage. Research conducted during this study found an even earlier Code -compliant proposal of an identically spelled genus-group name:
Sarcophaga Swinderen, 1822
(with
Musca vomitoria Linnaeus, 1758
[currently Calliphoridae ] as type species by monotypy). Under strict priority,
Sarcophaga Swinderen, 1822
is a senior homonym of
Sarcophaga Meigen, 1824
and a senior synonym of
Calliphora Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
. Adhering to strict priority would upset the well-known and widely used names
Sarcophaga
and
Calliphora
, which are in use as valid names for genera containing species of medical, veterinary and forensic importance, with several anthropophilic species, some of which have become largely cosmopolitan. Additionally, adhering to strict priority would be particularly confusing as
Sarcophaga
would have to be reinstated as the valid generic name for species that are currently considered under the name
Calliphora
, with profound implications for the family-group name Sarcophagidae . We are here invoking Reversal of Precedence (ICZN Code Article 23.9.2) to promote stability in nomenclature and treat
Sarcophaga Swinderen, 1822
as a nomen oblitum and both
Sarcophaga Meigen, 1824
and
Calliphora Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
as
nomina protecta .
Sarcophaga Swinderen, 1822
, to our knowledge, has not been used as a valid name since 1899 (and probably not used at all since its proposal), while
Sarcophaga Meigen
and
Calliphora Robineau-Desvoidy
have each been used in more than 25 works by at least 10 authors in the last 50 years and encompassing a span of not less than 10 years. Lists of these references (one list each for
Sarcophaga
and
Calliphora
) are given in Appendix II.

CURRENT STATUS: Subsequent usage of
Sarcophaga Meigen, 1824
.
FAMILY: SARCOPHAGIDAE .

subSubSection.paragraph: FAMILY: TACHINIDAE .

REMARKS : Problems involving the identity of
Siphona Meigen, 1803
(involving the ICZN as far back as 1945), led to Sabrosky (1971) summarizing the history and usage of the generic name and its type species in his application to the Commission for resolution. The name of the only species included in
Siphona
by Meigen (1803), “
Stomoxis irritans Fabr.
”, was never described by Fabricius and was essentially a misidentification by Meigen of a species misidentified by Fabricius that was in actuality
Musca geniculata De Geer, 1776
. The “
Stomoxis irritans
”, which was originally described as
Conops irritans Linnaeus, 1758
(now in
Haematobia Le Peletier & Audinet-Serville, 1828
[ Muscidae ]), if accepted as the type of
Siphona
, would threaten the long-established usage of
Siphona
in Tachinidae . To preserve the usage of
Siphona Meigen, 1803
, Sabrosky’s (1971) request to make
Musca geniculata De Geer, 1776
the type species of
Siphona
was voted in favor by the I.C.Z.N. (1974: 157 [Opinion 1008]).

Spania nigra Meigen, 1830a
.

TYPE SPECIES :
Spania nigra Meigen, 1830a
, by monotypy
.
FAMILY: SPANIIDAE .

by monotypy, acceptance of which would also place

as a junior synonym of
Pangonius Latreille, 1802

Tanyglossa
in Meigen (1803: 267) and listing of the single valid nominal species
Tabanus haustellata Fabricius, 1781
makes the genus-group name available from that work. Accepting
Tabanus haustellatus Fabricius, 1781
as the type species of
Tanyglossa Meigen, 1803
places this nominal genus as a senior synonym of Melanopangonius Szilády, 1923, new synonymy , new status , which is currently treated as a subgenus of
Pangonius Latreille, 1802
[
teste Chvála (1988: 100)

Hendel (1908) included one species,

258 .
Ulidia Meigen , 1826
: xi , 385 , pl . 53 .

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Musca demandata Fabricius, 1794
(with
Chrysomyza splendida Fallén, 1817d
in synonymy);
Ulidia erythrophthalma Meigen, 1826
(as “
Ulid. erythrophthalma
. Meg.”);
Ulidia nitida Meigen 1826
.

TYPE SPECIES :
Ulidia erythrophthalma Meigen, 1826
, by subsequent designation (Hennig 1940: 13)
.
FAMILY: ULIDIIDAE .

REMARKS: Sabrosky (1999: 318) gave a note indicating the possibility that Meigen (1826) could have proposed
Ulidia
as a new replacement name for
Chrysomyza Fallén, 1817d
. Meigen (1826: 386) made the statement “ Fallén bringt diese Gattung zur der Familie Scenopinii, womit sie doch nur eine sehr entfernte Aehnlichkeit hat, und heisst sie Chrysomyza weil er nur die erste Art kannte. Da dieser Name aber auf die andern nicht passt so heisse ich sie Ulidia ....” [Fallén puts this genus in the family Scenopinii, with which it has but a very distant resemblance, and it is called
Chrysomyza
because he knew only the first species. But as this name does not suit the others, I call it
Ulidia
.] This implies that Meigen was only using
Ulidia
for that portion of the species for which
Chrysomyza sensu Fallén, 1817d
does not fit.
Chrysomyza Fallén, 1817d
was based only on one species but Meigen met Fallén in July 1823 and we do not know what conversation or specimens were exchanged that might have included an expansion of what Fallén had considered as belonging in his
Chrysomyza
six years earlier. Meigen’s unpublished knowledge based on his meeting with Fallén in 1823 may well have been what he was referring to when he wrote that Fallén’s name
Chrysomyza
did not fit “the other species”. Thus, we believe this to not be a new replacement name for
Chrysomyza Fallén, 1817d
, but a separate proposal of a new nominal genus.

Earlier type designations of
Musca demandata Fabricius, 1794
(Guérin, 1830: 456; Westwood 1840: 149 Zetterstedt 1847: 2369; Blanchard in Audouin et al . 1848b: pl. 181bis; Desmarest in d’Orbigny 1849: 753 Rondani 1856: 115) exist, but if accepted, would upset the stability of nomenclature and taxonomy of
Ulidia Meigen, 1826
and
Physiphora Fallén, 1810
, because
Ulidia
would become a senior synonym of
Physiphora
and a new nominal genus would be needed for the species previously treated in
Ulidia
. An application to the ICZN to conserve
Ulidia
and
Physiphora
by setting aside all designations prior to that of Hennig (1940) is warranted.

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES :

(with “
Unomyia nubila ” Megerle
[
nomen nudum
] in synonymy);

(with
Tipula phragmitidis Schrank, 1781
, “
Unomyia lineola ” Megerle
[
nomen nudum
] and “
Unomyia trinotata ” Megerle
[
nomen nudum
] in synonymy);
Limnobia ornata Meigen, 1818a
(with “
Unomyia tessellata ” Megerle
[
nomen nudum
] in synonymy);
Limnobia annulus Meigen, 1818a
(with
Limonia quatuormaculata Meigen, 1804
and “
Unomyia tessullipennis ” Megerle
[
nomen nudum
] in synonymy).

TYPE SPECIES :
Tipula tripunctata Fabricius, 1781
, by subsequent designation (Coquillett 1910a: 618)
.

CURRENT STATUS : Junior synonym of
Limonia Meigen, 1803
[
teste Savchenko et al . (1992: 357)
].
FAMILY: LIMONIIDAE .

REMARKS:
Unomyia Meigen, 1818a
was originally published in synonymy (with
Limnobia
) and first made available by subsequent usage as a valid name in Macquart (1835: 652). Previous catalogers [e.g., Savchenko et al . (1992: 357)] have treated the type species
Tipula tripunctata Fabricius
as a junior synonym of
Tipula phragmatidis Schrank, 1781
. Evenhuis (1997) has dated Fabricius (1781) as published in March 1781 and Schrank (1781) as published in June 1781 . Thus,
Tipula tripunctata Fabricius, 1781
is the valid name for the type species.
[ Uromyia ] Meigen , 1838 : viii , 202 .

CURRENT STATUS: Incorrect subsequent spelling of
Uramya Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
.
FAMILY: TACHINIDAE .

Remarks: Although this name might be construed as being made available as an emendation by virtue of similar spelling changes in two or more names from “mya” to “myia” in the same work, the earliest mention of
Uramya Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
that we have found using the spelling “
Uramyia
” is
Uramyia Macquart (1834a: 428)
as an unjustified emendation [
teste Evenhuis et al . (2016: 126)
]. Because of the equivocal usage of name in this work, we invoke ICZN Code Article 33.5 and treat all usages of “
Uramyia
” by Meigen (1838) as incorrect subsequent spellings of
Uramya Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830
. Some authors (e.g., Scudder 1882; Townsend 1891, 1908; Neave 1940b) have treated this as a separate proposal of a new genus-group name by Meigen, but it is doubtful Meigen would have proposed the same nominal genus-group name (in its misspelled or emended form) as Robineau-Desvoidy (1830) within the Tachinidae . Although the generic concepts based on the included species by Meigen (1838: 202) are different from that of
Uramya Robineau-Desvoidy (1830)
, we believe Meigen knew of the genus and was trying to fit his species into it. See also Remarks to ‘Actia’ of Neave (1939a) below.

263 .
Xysta Meigen , 1824
: xii , 181 , pl . 39 .

ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES:
Xysta cilipes Meigen, 1824
;
Thereva holosericea Fabricius, 1805
.

TYPE
SPECIES
:
Xysta cilipes Meigen, 1824
[=
Thereva holosericea Fabricius, 1805
], by subsequent designation (Blanchard in Audouin et al. 1846: pl. 177bis).
FAMILY: TACHINIDAE .

REMARKS: Herting & Dely-Draskovits (1993: 414) gave the type fixation for
Xysta
as
Xysta cilipes Meigen, 1824
by subsequent designation by Rondani (1856: 82). However, Blanchard in Audouin et al. (1846: pl. 177bis) designated the same species and was earlier. Westwood (1840: 140) designated a “
X. cana Hal.
”, which was never described by Haliday, but Westwood may have meant
Phasia cana Meigen, 1824
(which was later transferred to
Xysta
), but in each case the designation is invalid as it is either of a
nomen nudum
or of a species not originally included.
EMENDATIONS: Xista Rondani, 1856: 82 (unjustified).
[Zelima] Meigen , 1800 : 34 .

CURRENT STATUS: Unavailable name; work suppressed for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]); treated under
Xylota Meigen, 1822
[
teste Sabrosky (1999: 325)
].
FAMILY: SYRPHIDAE .
REMARKS : Subsequently made available by Hendel (1903) [see Evenhuis & Pape (2017: 57)].
[ Zelmira ] Meigen , 1800 : 16 .

CURRENT STATUS: Unavailable name; work suppressed for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]); treated under
Orfelia
Costa , 1857 [
teste Evenhuis (2006: 89)
].
FAMILY: KEROPLATIDAE .
REMARKS: Subsequently made available by Meigen in Hendel (1908) (see next entry).

264 .
Zelmira Meigen
in Hendel
, 1908 : 48 .
ORIGINALLY INCLUDED SPECIES: None.

FIRST INCLUDED SPECIES:
Platyura fasciata Meigen, 1803
(in Coquillett 1910a: 621).

TYPE SPECIES :
Platyura fasciata Meigen, 1803
, by subsequent designation (Coquillett 1910a: 621)
.

CURRENT STATUS : Junior synonym of
Orfelia
Costa , 1857 [
teste Evenhuis & Pape (2017: 58)
].
FAMILY: KEROPLATIDAE .

REMARKS:
Zelmira
was originally proposed by Meigen (1800: 16) without included species and later made unavailable by the suppression of the work for the purposes of zoological nomenclature by action of I.C.Z.N. (1963: 339 [Opinion 678]). Hendel (1908: 48) was the first after Meigen (1800) to give characters to differentiate the taxon (reproducing Meigen’s characters) and to treat it as a valid name, which makes the name available from that work with Meigen as author. Hendel (1908) did not include any species. Coquillett (1910a: 621) was the first to include a species:
Platyura fasciata Meigen, 1803
, which is the type species

by subsequent designation.
Platyura fasciata Meigen, 1803
is currently treated in
Orfelia
Costa , 1857 [
teste Evenhuis (2006: 89)
], which makes
Zelmira Meigen
in Hendel, 1908 a junior synonym of
Orfelia
Costa , 1857. When Coquillett (1910a: 617) selected
Platyura fasciata Meigen, 1803
as type species for
Zelmira
, that species was treated in
Platyura Meigen, 1803
.
Platyura fasciata Meigen, 1803
has subsequently been classified as a species of
Orfelia
Costa , 1857, where we treat it here.
